answer_html: \(\lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10}\frac{10(1+1/k)^{2}}{(2 + 2/k)(2 + 1/k)}=\frac{10}{4} > 1\) Since \(c > 1\), this series diverges by the ratio test.
answer_latex: $\lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10}\frac{10(1+1/k)^{2}}{(2 + 2/k)(2 + 1/k)}=\frac{10}{4} > 1$  Since $c > 1$, this series diverges by the ratio test.
hints_html: Given the appearance of factorial terms in the series, you might try applying the ratio test.
hints_latex:
Given the appearance of factorial terms in the series, you might try
applying the ratio test.
hints_raw: Given the appearance of factorial terms in the series, you might try applying the <b>ratio test</b>.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
We apply the ratio test for this problem. Let

\[\begin{aligned} \quad c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left| \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}}\right|, \quad a_{k} = \frac{k^{10}10^{k}(k!)^{2}}{(2k)!}.\end{aligned}\]

By the ratio test, if \(c < 1\), then the series converges. If \(c > 1\), the series diverges. If \(c = 1\), then no conclusion can be drawn. For \(k > 0\), all \(a_{k}\) are positive so we can remove the absolute value signs in \(c\) when evaluating it.

\[\begin{aligned} c &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left| \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}}\right| = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^{10}10^{k+1}((k+1)!)^{2}}{(2(k+1))!}\frac{(2k)!}{k^{10}10^{k}(k!)^{2}} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^{10}}{k^{10}}\frac{10^{k+1}}{10^{k}}\frac{((k+1)!)^{2}}{(k!)^{2}}\frac{(2k)!}{(2k+2)!}\end{aligned}\]

Using the fact that \((k+1)! = (k+1)\cdot k!\) and \((2k+2)! = (2k+2)\cdot(2k+1)\cdot(2k)!\) we can simplify the fractions with factorial terms, giving us the following:

\[\begin{aligned} c &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)^{10} \cdot 10 \cdot (k+1)^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{(2k + 2)(2k + 1)} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10} \cdot \frac{10(k+1)^{2}}{(2k + 2)(2k + 1)} \end{aligned}\]

Dividing both the numerator and denominator by \(k^{2}\) gives:

\[\begin{aligned} &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10}\frac{10(1+1/k)^{2}}{(2 + 2/k)(2 + 1/k)}\\ &= \frac{10}{4} > 1\end{aligned}\]

Since \(c > 1\), this series diverges by the ratio test.
sols_latex:
We apply the ratio test for this problem. Let

\begin{align*}
\quad c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left| \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}}\right|, \quad a_{k} = \frac{k^{10}10^{k}(k!)^{2}}{(2k)!}.
\end{align*}
By the ratio test, if $c < 1$, then the series converges. If $c > 1$,
the series diverges. If $c = 1$, then no conclusion can be drawn. For
$k > 0$, all $a_{k}$ are positive so we can remove the absolute value
signs in $c$ when evaluating it.

\begin{align*}
c &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left| \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}}\right| = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^{10}10^{k+1}((k+1)!)^{2}}{(2(k+1))!}\frac{(2k)!}{k^{10}10^{k}(k!)^{2}} \\
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^{10}}{k^{10}}\frac{10^{k+1}}{10^{k}}\frac{((k+1)!)^{2}}{(k!)^{2}}\frac{(2k)!}{(2k+2)!}
\end{align*} Using the fact that $(k+1)! = (k+1)\cdot k!$ and
$(2k+2)! = (2k+2)\cdot(2k+1)\cdot(2k)!$ we can simplify the fractions
with factorial terms, giving us the following:

\begin{align*}
c &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)^{10} \cdot 10 \cdot (k+1)^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{(2k + 2)(2k + 1)} \\ 
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10} \cdot \frac{10(k+1)^{2}}{(2k + 2)(2k + 1)} 
\end{align*} Dividing both the numerator and denominator by $k^{2}$
gives:

\begin{align*}
&= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10}\frac{10(1+1/k)^{2}}{(2 + 2/k)(2 + 1/k)}\\ 
&= \frac{10}{4} > 1
\end{align*} Since $c > 1$, this series diverges by the ratio test.
sols_raw:
We apply the <b>ratio test</b> for this problem. Let
:<math>
\quad c = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left| \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}}\right|, \quad a_{k} = \frac{k^{10}10^{k}(k!)^{2}}{(2k)!}.
</math>
By the ratio test, if <math>c < 1</math>, then the series converges. If <math>c > 1</math>, the series diverges. If <math>c = 1</math>, then no conclusion can be drawn. For <math>k > 0</math>, all <math>a_{k}</math> are positive so we can remove the absolute value signs in <math>c</math> when evaluating it.
:<math>
\begin{align}
c &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty}\left| \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}}\right| = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_{k}} \\
& = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^{10}10^{k+1}((k+1)!)^{2}}{(2(k+1))!}\frac{(2k)!}{k^{10}10^{k}(k!)^{2}} \\
& = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(k+1)^{10}}{k^{10}}\frac{10^{k+1}}{10^{k}}\frac{((k+1)!)^{2}}{(k!)^{2}}\frac{(2k)!}{(2k+2)!}
\end{align}
</math>
Using the fact that <math>(k+1)! = (k+1)\cdot k!</math> and <math>(2k+2)! = (2k+2)\cdot(2k+1)\cdot(2k)!</math> we can simplify the fractions with factorial terms, giving us the following:
:<math>
\begin{align}
c & = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)^{10} \cdot 10 \cdot (k+1)^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{(2k + 2)(2k + 1)} \\ 
& = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10} \cdot \frac{10(k+1)^{2}}{(2k + 2)(2k + 1)} 
\end{align}
</math>
Dividing both the numerator and denominator by <math>k^{2}</math> gives:
:<math>
\begin{align}
& = \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} \left(1 + \frac{1}{k} \right)^{10}\frac{10(1+1/k)^{2}}{(2 + 2/k)(2 + 1/k)}\\ 
& = \frac{10}{4} > 1
\end{align}
</math>
<font style="color:blue">Since <math>c > 1</math>, this series diverges by the ratio test.</font>
statement_html:
This problem contains three numerical series. For each of them, find out whether it converges or diverges. You should provide appropriate justification in order to receive credit.

(b)

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k = 1}^{\infty}\frac{k^{10}10^{k}(k!)^{2}}{(2k)!}\,.\end{aligned}\]
